body:
The change seems to actually fix an issue with wrong y positions, @NathanSweet will probably be able to explain the change but, have you confirmed by opening the atlas file the pixel positions it refers to are actually wrong or you're assuming they're wrong based on the screenshots?

The effect on the screenshots is called texture bleeding and it may occur with a correct atlas (correct pixel positions) due to OpenGL texture filtering. The fix is usually to add a small 2px padding between sprites.

Thanks @obigu, yes I've checked the atlas file and `y` position are wrong, I've also cut them with photoshop and it's clear visible that pixels overlap other sprites. Indeed, the new output format produce correct `y` values. You can check is the PNG and two atlases generated:
![pack](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5543339/145419942-98b64c6c-0f69-4728-b7d2-2b8e1ce1a094.png)
[pack.atlas.txt](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/files/7686044/pack.atlas.txt)
[pack-new.atlas.txt](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/files/7686048/pack-new.atlas.txt)

Anyway, I've switched to the new atlas file format which is much more compact and y are correctly calculated... I didn't understand why this change is needed, but if it's an intended behavior maybe mark it as break change :)
Thanks for providing the extra info. It definitely looks like a bug. Let's wait for Nate's answer.

The commit that caused this problem was trying to fix a bug that I fixed in the Spine texture packer (which is a fork). I ported the fix and tested it, but I just retested it and fgnm is right, the fix is bad. I'll revert it. Very sorry for the trouble!

Hello,

i also use Hyperlap and the new atlas file. And sadly ive the same Problems:

**Inside Editor:**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73443724/145716509-635c4d0b-35ed-457b-9436-27587052f259.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73443724/145716539-98c22407-49f3-4722-94f9-66f92939252c.png)

**Atlas file (cutout):**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73443724/145716651-189fa32c-6c34-4359-8b75-7359a321bae9.png)

Sometimes the error is corrected with a repack / new import. Unfortunately not this time.

**Update:** If I use the "old" legacy Libgdx format, there are no errors.

This is the working old format atlas file:


@aallnneess you're not using any padding, and that's what happens when you don't use padding. Your situation has x and y both too close to other textures, not just y. This is not the same as the original issue (where the new atlas format never had issues, but the legacy format did have incorrect y), and is also something that is very frequently addressed on the Discord. You probably just need to add 2px of padding.
